theText: Wednesday, 8 June 1994 MAIN COMMITTEE 1725 Wednesday, 8 June 1994 item of business for consideration, it might be appropriate if I outline some matters of practice and procedure relating to the Main Committee deliberations. The proceedings of the Main Committee are very much proceedings of the parliament and, as such, warrant the same respect as those conducted in the House of Representatives chamber. As a general rule, the practice and procedure observed in the chamber will apply in the Main Committee unless the standing orders specifically provide otherwise. Consequently, for example, members wiIl be required to acknowledge the chair on entering or leaving, will rise to seek the call and will address the Committee standing unless incapacitated. Remarks must be addressed through the chair and members moving within the room in which the Committee is meeting must not pass between the chair and the member addressing the Committee. The speech time limits applying for consideration of business in the House apply in the Main Committee. Where an extension of time is available under the standing orders it will also apply in the Main Committee. However, it will not be possible for standing and sessional orders to be suspended in the Main Committee for the purpose of providing for an extended speech time or for any other purpose. One aspect of the Main Committee that differs from the House of Representatives chamber relates to the seating for members. No seats are reserved for specific m-mbers. It would be expected that government members would be seated to the right of the chair, and nongovernment members to the left. Members should address the occupant of the chair as 'Deputy. Speaker', whether the chair is occupied by me, the Second Deputy Speaker or a member of the Speaker's panel. Other members should be referred to by the name of the electoral division they represent or the office they hold. The standing orders provide that the quorum of this Committee shall comprise the occupant of the chair, one government member and one non-government member. Under the standing orders, if the chair takes note that a quorum is not present, proceedings are to be suspended or the Committee is to be adjourned. . Proceedings of the Committee must be suspended to enable members to attend any division in the House. The lights activated by the ringing of the bells will operate in this room, but the bells will be muted. Advice will be relayed directly from the chamber as to whether a division is in progress or a quorum is required and proceedings in the Committee will be suspended if a division is occurring. Committee proceedings will recommence when the chair here is resumed. Should the House adjourn, the· Committee must be adjourned forthwith by the chair. The Committee will be adjourned by the chair on completion of consideration of matters referred to it. Every question in the committee is to be decided on the voices. It is not possible for the committee to divide on a question and any dissent from the result announced by the chair is to be recorded in the minutes as an unresolved question for decision by. the House. theText: Order! Before the Clerk of the Committee calls on the first1726 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 8 June 1994 Committee may continue proceedings on a bill regardless of unresolved questions unless agreement to an unresolved question is necessary to enable further questions to be considered. In this case the Committee shall return the bill to the House for further consideration. Any member may move at any time during consideration of the Main Committee for further proceedings on a bill to be conducted in the House, and the motion shall be determined without amendment or debate. The official record of proceedings of the Main Committee will be the minutes of proceedings of the committee kept by the Clerk of the Committee, and will form part of the Votes and Proceedings of the House for the sitting during which the committee meets. A transcript of proceedings will be produced and will form part of the Hansard repo.rt of the House for that day. A sub-table office for the purposes of the Main Committee is located at the rear of this room. Staff, advisers, members of the media and other passholders will be required to enter this room by means of the central corridor. Members of the public will also enter and leave by these central corridor doors. Members may, of course, use all entry and exit points. However, the door in the north-eastern corner-towards the House of Representatives sidewill be reserved for entry and exit by members. Given the significance of this first meeting of the Main Committee, permission has been given for the taking of photographs for official and media purposes. The same guidelines will apply to the taking of photographs by the media. The signal of proceedings will be carried throughout the building by the House monitoring service. As a general rule, the guidelines applying to television camera operators in the chamber will apply to coverage of the Main Committee. The physical arrangements for the Main Committee enable members of the public and others to be much closer to where consideration of legislation and other matters is taking place than is possible in the House of Representatives chamber. However, the area allotted to members in this room is clearly delineated, and the integrity of that area must be respected at all times. The first mee!ing of the Main Committee heralds a new era in the deliberations of the parliament. There has been much discussion about and interest in the proposed operation of this Committee. I am sure that, with the cooperation of all members,the Main Committee will make the positive contribution to the workings of the House of Representatives envisaged by the Standing Committee on Procedure. Consideration resumed from 9 May. Second Reading congratulate you on your launching of this very interesting innovation in the conduct of parliamentary practice in this country. I know that we will all take heed of the strictures that you have placed upon us in terms of our conduct in this chamber. I move: That the bill be now read a second time. This bill amends the Superannuation Act 1976, the Superannuation Legislation Amendment Act 1990, the Superannuation Act 1990 and the Superannuation Benefits (Supervisory Mechanisms) Act 1990. These acts relate to the provision of superannuation benefits to civilian Commonwealth sector employees.

theText: Minister for Finance) (10.06 a.m.)Mr Deputy Speaker, may IWednesday, 8 June 1994 MAIN COMMITTEE 1727 The main purpose of the bill is to make amendments to allow superannuation schemes for Commonwealth civilian employees to comply with the .Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993 and associated legislation. The bill also makes some technical corrections. The Government decided that its own superannuation schemes that were at least partly funded should comply with the occupational superannuation requirements in the SIS legislation in the same way as private sector schemes. Commonwealth schemes that are not funded will be required to comply in principle with the major thrust of the controls, such as vesting and preservation. Among other things, the SIS legislation requires that the rules of a superannuation fund may not allow the trustees of the fund to be directed by another person, nor may any other person exercise discretions unilaterally. In addition, the rules of the fund should not be able to be amended without the approval of the' trustees. All these rules have some exceptions spelled out in the SI(S) Act itself, and some to be provided for by regulations under that act. The main exception relates to directions, discretions et cetera that would affect the employer's contributions to the fund. Currently, the Superannuation Act 1976 provides that the Commissioner for Superannuation and a board of trustees share the responsibility for the administration for the scheme set up by the act, the Commonwealth superannuation scheme or CSS. The bill gives the responsibility for administration of the CSS completely to the board of trustees. All discretionary decisions that were previously made by the commissioner will be made by the board from 1 July 1994. The Minister for Finance also has a role under the 1976 act. Some of the powers exercised by the minister are to be transferred to the board. However, other powers which relate to employer costs under the scheme will remain with the minister. Certain other powers were exercisable by the board after consideration of principles issued by the minister. In the case of these powers, the act generally has been amended to incorporate into the legislation any principles that were issued, and any remaining discretion is to be exercised by agreement between the minister and the board. Similar amendments concerning the powers of the minister are to be made to the Superannuation Act 1990. The scheme established under the provisions of that act is already administered by a board of trustees, so no transfer of power from the Commissioner for Superannuation is necessary. I emphasise that no changes are to be made to the benefit structure or the scheme design of the schemes covered by the acts that are being amended. One of the technical changes being made is to allow certain delegated instruments to operate with retrospective effect and to put the validity of past instruments beyond doubt. These amendments are a response to concerns raised by the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. The instruments would enable members to continue membership in circumstances where they may have inadvertently been forced to leave the scheme if there was no retrospectivity. The bill also amends the Superannuation Benefits (Supervisory Mechanisms) Act 1990. This act enables the Minister for Finance to exercise certain di§,cretions to oversight and control superannuation arrangements established by Commonwealth employing authorities other than the Commonwealth itself. Consistent with the SI(S) Act, the existing ministerial discretions would be replaced with provisions preventing Commonwealth employers from establishing and operating superannuation arrangements unless they are able to satisfy certain predetermined 1728 MAIN COMMITIEE Wednesday, 8 June 1994 requirements. An added feature of these requirements is that they will impose an obligation on employers to report annually to the minister in relation to those arrangements. I now turn to the financial impact of the bill. As none of the changes result in any change to the benefit designed for superannuation schemes involved, there is no financial impact. Mr Deputy Speaker, I commend the bill to the Committee. Deputy Speaker. Beazley), in marking the inauguration of the Main Committee. It is, as the Leader of the House said, something of an experiment in the parliamentary life of Australia. I hope it goes well. The opposition takes the view that it will give the mechanism of the Main Committee its best shot. If the Main Committee can add to the intelligent dispatch of business and, in this rather more intimate atmosphere, lift the quality of debate on some of the less contentious but nonetheless detailed pieces of legislation, the whole parliamentary system and the community will be the beneficiaries. I have a couple of remarks about the ambience of the room. In the short time available, the people responsible, and I compliment the Deputy Clerk as their representative, have done quite well. There might be some consideration given to placing an Australian coat of arms behind the Deputy Speaker's chair. If that is decided on, I hope that is the full-blown coat of arms and not the terribly short one. I like the full-blown one with the wattle in its complete lustre and bloom. I can promise him that one thing we will not forget is the Speaker's chair when we win the next election, but it will be going back into the main chamber. There could be some consideration given to a few other adornments in this room. However, we will do our best to make the Main Committee work; I hope it does. I thank the Clerk and the others responsible for assembling things. It will be a very interesting exercise. of his remarks. I say to the honourable member for Banks that it was predictable that he would make the first interjection in this place. through you, to the clerks, and I express the wish that this chamber succeeds in the objectives set for it by the government. The Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 was introduced into the House on 9 May after it passed through the Senate on 5 May. It was referred to the Main Committee on 2 June, making it the first of several bills to be referred to this Committee. The bill sets out to ensure the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme, CSS, and the Public Sector Superanriuation Scheme, PSS, are compatible with the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993, known as the SI(S) Act, and with associated legislation. This is a goal which the coalition agrees with, no matter what concerns we may have with the provisions of the SI(S) Act. Therefore, the coalition does not oppose the legislation. theText: Mr Deputy Speaker, I add my best wishes to you and,Wednesday, 8 June 1994 MAIN .COMMITTEE 1729 begins operating from 1 July 1994, makes provision for the prudent management of certain superannuation funds and for oversight by the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner. In particular, the SI(S) Act aims to ensure that members' moneys are as secure as-possible. Although the SI(S) Act allows for certain public sector superannuation schemes to be exempted from it, the government has nevertheless decided that all Commonwealth superannuation schemes with an invested fund will comply with the SI(S) Act. This is the first measure to ensure that Commonwealth schemes comply with the SI(S) Act. Further legislation, such as the Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill 1994, has been introduced with the stated aim of bringing all Commonwealth superannuation schemes with the SI(S) Act. For the infonnation of the Main Committee and others, this bill will bring the parliamentarians' superannuation scheme within the SI(S) Act. Those without an invested fund will still need to comply with the main requirements of the principal act, such as preservation. In order to ensure that Commonwealth superannuation schemes can continue to be eligible for taxation concessions after 1 July 1994, the governing rules for those schemes, including the legislation, are to be amended. The main thrust of the proposed amendments is to give trustees greater responsibility for and control over the administration of the scheme. This results in the powers of the relevant minister in the role of employer being diminished in some ways and shared with the trustees in other ways. In other instances, discretions previously exercisable by the minister have been replaced by specific provisions in this legislation. Importantly, the SI(S) Act provides exemptions so that employers are able to retain control of decisions, discretions and amendments which affect the cost to the employer of a scheme. The Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill before us will amend four acts. They are: the Superannuation Act 1976, the Superannuation Legislation Amendment Act 1990, the Superannuation Act 1990 and the Superannuation Benefits (Supervisory Mechanisms) Act 1990. The vast majority of amendments are made to the Superannuation Act 1976, however, which is the act that established the CSS. Several amendments are made to this act. They are mostly of a technical nature and include the powers and role of the trustees of the CSS, ensuring that the rules of the CSS enable the payment of certain. unclaimed benefits to eligible rollover funds as required by the SI(S) Act; providing for the making of and saving of previously made retrospective regulations and other legislative instruments under certain provisions of the act in order to ensure continuing membership of the scheme in certain circumstances and certain other technical amendments that ensure that references to other legislation are correct and that the CSS complies with the SI(S) Act. The Superannuation Legislation Amendment Act 1990 amended the 1976 act as well as other acts as a result of the review of superannuation for Commonwealth employees that led to the introduction of the superannuation scheme provided for by the Superannuation Act 1990. This bill proposes to amend the amending act to correct a technical deficiency in one of its provisions. The Superannuation Act 1990, the 1990 act in brief, provided for the establishment of the PSS under a trust deed and rule. This bill amends the 1990 act in several ways, including changes to the power and role of the trustees that mirror the changes to the CSS, as stated, providing a regulations making power to enable alternations to the 1990 act so that it can easily comply with future amendments to the SI(S) act, its regulations and other 1730 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 8 June 1994 regulatory laws and mirror the changes to the CSS so as to provide for the making of and saving of previously made retrospective regulations and other legislative instruments. The Superannuation Benefits (Supervisory Mechanisms) Act of 1990 allows discretions to be exercised by the Minister for Finance on the oversight and control over the provision by Commonwealth employees of superannuation benefits for their employees outside the CSS and PSS. The amendment to this act enables the Minister for Finance to maintain strategic control of Commonwealth employing authorities superannuation schemes in a manner that is consistent with the SI(S) Act. Under these amendments, Commonwealth employers will not be able to establish and operate superannuation schemes, unless they are able to satisfy certain requirements that are predetermined by the minister. The amendments proposed in this bill do not alter in any way, shape or form, the financial entitlement accruing to members of the CSS and PSS. Overall these amendments benefit the members of the two Commonwealth superannuation schemes, because members will now have access to the superannuation complaints tribunal, with its low cost dispute resolution mechanisms. Fund members will also maintain access to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, giving members a choice of process by which they can seek redress if they feel hard done by. These amendments are also reaSsuring for Commonwealth public servants because their funds will not be protected in the same way as private sector funds are by the provisions of the SIS legislation. This is especially important because invested funds in the CSS and PSS will be subject to the SI(S) Act's prudential standards, which become effective on 1 July this year. Though the SI(S) Act exempted certain public sector schemes from these controls, this legislation brings nearly all Commonwealth public servants under SIS provisions. Many state schemes are apparently unable to comply with the SI(S) Act at this stage, but are expected to be able to do so in the near future, I understand. The legislation currently before us is fairly straightforward and does not involve a great deal of contention or controversy. However, some aspects of the CSS and PSS warrant discussion, as well as some more general superannuation issues which. relate to the SI(S) Act. As honourable members are aware, no doubt, there are no employer contributions from the Commonwealth to meet future claims upon the CSS, and only very limited contributions to the PSS. On retirement, the employer component of the CSS and most of the PSS comes from consolidated revenue. That means, in effect, that, for the CSS alone, there was an unfunded liability of $33 billion as at 30 June 1992. That was a liability of $1,903 a head for every Australian man, woman and child. For the PSS, the employer contribution is only three per cent of salary. This leaves the remaining 12.4 per cent unfunded. However, the government's potential liability does not end there. In the CSS, employee contributions are invested by Commonwealth Funds Management, CFM, with returns to employees based on investment outcomes. In the PSS though, employee contributions are invested by the CFM, but the return is guaranteed and not limited to investment returns. The Commonwealth thereby has to make up any shortfall that occurs, further exposing consolidated revenue in the future to the need to payout PSS members on retirement. A fully funded superannuation scheme is arguably the most desirable scheme to have in place. The strongest argument in support of full funding concerns the principle of intergenerational equity. Put simply, it is more equitable that the cost of liabilities currently Wednesday, 8 June 1994 MAIN COMMITTEE 1731 incurred should be met by the current generation and should not be left to be paid for by future generat-pns. Future generations may not have the capacity to pay the superannuation of their predecessors. This lessening of fiscal responsibilities severely inhibits the ability of future generations to make the necessary decisions on where expenditure would be best allocated. P.P. McGuinness in two columns in the Australian of 1 February and 5 February amongst other things said: The ageing of the Australian population is a problem that is attracting increasing attention as we look forward to the next century. What has now become quite clear is that the baby boomer generation has created a burden that will blight their children's lives. This blight will occur because the children of the baby boomer generation will, according to McGuinness, be left to pay the unfunded superannuation and pensions of their parents, as well as the mounting bills for health and nursing homes. McGuinness, even if somewhat emotive, has mounted a good case for fully funded future public and private sector superannuation. Superannuation is also an important component of labour costs, and governments should be recognising these costs and paying for them as they occur. This could have the added bonus of giving governments increased resolve to keep staff numbers under control and inhibit government from engaging in activities for which there is no real benefit to the community at large. Fully funded schemes would also have the advantage that governments would need to keep schemes within economic levels. One of the few arguments against the full funding of public sector superannuation is that, while Australia is, a net borrower, it does not make sense to borrow further in order to fund public sector superannuation. Although that is a valid point, and there are some others, the reasons for establishing fully funded schemes are more persuasive. The government, when establishing the PSS in 1990, took the decision to partially fund that particular scheme to avoid a large increase in unfunded liability. So at least the government is aware of the problem. The government, when establishing the PSS, not only made it partially funded; it reduced the level of future entitlements due to fund members. This has been achieved by reducing the new entrant contribution rate-that is, average employer contribution expressed as a percentage of salary from 22.8 per cent to 15.4 per cent. The Commonwealth is not the only government to reduce the level of its contribution: New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia have all created new public sector superannuation schemes that are partially funded with reduced employer contributions. As of 30 June 1992, Victoria's unfunded superannuation liabilities amounted to $18 billion, which is $4,063 for each and every citizen of the state of Victoria' and it is the worse liability of any state fund in the nation. New South Wales's unfunded liability was $13.9 billion, at the same level of employer contribution as Victoria-that is, 21.5 per cent-while Western Australia, after Victoria, had the highest per capita liability of $2,694. This is a reflection on the previous Cain and Kirner governments in Victoria that destroyed Victoria's fiscal base, in one of the worse examples of economic vandalism, by employing more public servants from 1982 to 1988 than all the other state governments and the federal government combined. These extra public servants became an impossible fiscal burden to carry, in terms of their wages and on-costs, as well as the added future cost of massive increases in unfunded superannuation liabilities in that state. It is small wonder that, in those circumstances, the Kennett government has been reducing the size of the Victorian Public Service. Both the 1732 MAIN COMMITIEE Wednesday, 8 June 1994 Commonwealth and the states as at 30 June 1992 had total unfunded superannuation liabilities of $80 billion, with this figure rising to $90 billion when local government is also taken into account. This is an extremely large burden that tomorrow's taxpayers will have to carry. Queensland is the only state that has a fully funded superannuation scheme which, though a modest scheme, is affordable. Ms Crawford-Hear, hear! for that, and I am sure the honourable, member who just said, 'Hear, hear!' would agree with me. He should be remembered as the Australian state premier who established Queensland's excellent financial state of affairs, which the current Goss Labor government has inherited. It is time that all government public sector superannuation schemes become fully funded and meet the requirements of the SI(S) Act. Another superannuation issue that I have spoken about in the past is the operation of the superannuation guarantee charge, which discriminates against many casual, part-time and itinerant workers. The coalition has received many representations from working men and women in Australia who have been affected by the rules current applying to the SGC. These problems were acknowledged by the then Treasurer as long ago as August 1993, when he announced that the government would give high priority to resolving the problems experienced by casual and itinerant workers under the SGC scheme. I seer it has surfaced again, and we are getting the same assurances as we had in 1993, but we still have very little to show for them. This is a problem which requires a strong government response. If the government had addressed the issue in the past two years, or as long as two years ago, lower income earners would now have a rational superannuation system. Sections 27 and 28 of the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992 are, at the heart of the problem that penalises casual, part-time and itinerant workers, and penalises them very severely, indeed. Casual and itinerant workers often work for many employers and change jobs regularly, resulting at the moment in membership of multiple and separate superannuation schemes. Administration fees and exit fees whittle away those funds because they take no account of the available balance. For example, a worker earning $600 per month would receive a superannuation contribution from his or her employer of $18 per month, or an annual benefit of $216. However, there is a contribution tax of 15 per cent that reduces the balance to $184, and there is a further administration charge of $50. The remaining balance is only $134-$82 is gobbled up by taxes and administration fees. What hope does this hold for a worker who works only a few hours a week or who can get only occasional work? .Many of these schemes, into wnich contributions are made by the employer, often lie dormant after a casual worker has moved on to another job. These dormant superannuation schemes, if more than $500-or less than $500, but not withdrawn from the super fund-will continue to be charged an administration fee of approximately $50 per year or, at best, a dormant account fee of $26. There are also the exit fees when workers decide to rationalise their superannuation holdings. These provisions penalise women disproportionately to men, as women are more likely to work in part-time positions and occupations that are less well paid. I have mentioned several solutions to that problem in the past in the chamber, so I am not going to regurgitate them here. . Mr Deputy Speaker, the matter before us today, the first day of operation of this place, is the Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill 1994. The main purpose of this bill is to enable the Commonwealth superannuation arrangements for civilian employees in the COmnionwealth superannuation scheme, the CSS, and the public sector superannuation scheme, the PSS, to comply with revisions of the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993, the SICS) Act, and associated legislation which largely come into operation from 1 July 1994. It will do this by amending the four acts dealing with superannuation for Commonwealth sector civilian employees. These acts are: the Superannuation Act 1976; the Superannuation Legislation Amendment Act 1990; the Superannuation Act 1990; and the Superannuation Benefits (Supervisory Mechanisms) Act 1990. The SICS) Act takes effect from 1 July this year, and makes provision for the prudent management of certain superannuation funds in particular, to ensure that members' money is as secure as possible. This is understandably a matter of great concern to the public. It will also allow the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner to supervise its operations, another very important aspect.

speaker: Mr Les Scott (Oxley) (10.36 A.m
theText: )Mr Deputy Speaker, with your indulgence,could1734 MAIN COMMiTTEE Wednesday, 8 June 1994 The government decided that its own superannuation schemes that were at least partly funded should comply with the occupational superannuation requirements in the SIS legislation in much the same way as private sector schemes. Commonwealth schemes that are not funded will be required to comply, at least in principle, with the major thrust of the controls such as vesting and preservation. Commonwealth superannuation schemes with invested funds will consequently come under the supervision of the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner, who is responsible for ensuring that superannuation funds comply with provisions for prudent management in the SI(S) Act. The Commonwealth superannuation schemes without invested funds will also comply with the requirements of the SI(S) Act such as preservation and benefits and vesting. The main provisions of the bill are intended to ensure that the CSS and the PSS comply with the SIS legislation in the following key respects. Subsection 58(1) of the SI(S) Act requires that the trustees should not be subject to direction by any other person except to the extent permitted by subsection 58(2) and the regulations. This will require the removal or limitation of the power of the minister to issue statements of government policy and principles of various matters to be followed by the boards. Paragraphs 4.1, 4.6 and 4.16 actually apply to that. Subsection 59(1) and the SI(S) Act provide that a person other than a trustee must not be in a position to exercise discretion except in certain limited circumstances permitted by subsection 59(2) and the regulations in paragraphs 4.7 and 4.15. This legislation is all about providing adequate control and supervision over money built up by members of superannuation funds. These amendments will mean that the Commonwealth funds will comply with the SIS legislation. This is a very good idea, of course, and to illustrate this I will remind honourable members of the nature and the intent of the SIS legislation. Among other things, it requires that the rules of a superannuation fund not allow trustees to the fund to be directed by another person, and that no other person may exercise discretion in that group. In addition, the rules of the fund should not be able to be amended without the approval of the trustees. As you can imagine, this places a great onus on the trustees to provide the fund members with regular, quality information about the ongoing operation and performance of the fund. The CSS and PSS schemes are examples of funds that are doing this, and the managers of these schemes should be commended for their commitment to adequate protection for their members. The main benefit that will flow from these amendments is that they will give trustees greater responsibilities for, and control over, the scheme. This implies, of course, that they will also have higher standards to match regarding prudent supervision of the funds. Mr Deputy Speaker, it is important to note that these proposed amendments do not alter the benefit design of the schemes provided for by the legislation, so there is no net financial impact of this bill. The members of the Commonwealth superannuation funds will not lose any money from this, but they will gain increased protection. Under this legislation, the trustees of both the CSS and the PSS are not subject to any direction from any person except the minister, as provided for under the SI(S) Act. This is reassuring for Commonwealth public servants, as they will know that their funds will now be protected in the same way as the private sector funds are protected under the SI(S) Act. This is a debate that has raged for some time now, but there is nothing wrong with that. We are, after all, talking about very large sums of money in these funds. The topic of the adequate supervision of superannuation funds has received a great deal of attention over the last few years. To illustrate the necessity for the changes outlined in the legislation currently before Wednesday, 8 June 1994 MAIN COMMITTEE 1735 us, I take the opportunity to remind honourable members of what the parliamentary banking inquiry, which I was involved in, said two years ago. The report of the inquiry recommended that 'a council of financial supervisors be established to facilitate closer coordination between the supervisors of the financial system'. Whilst the Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill does not propose to set up any such council, the important point in that quote was the necessity for better coordination, and these amendments will help to achieve this. As I said before, the legislation will place greater standards on trustees. This is a very important part of any superannuation scheme. This was another point that arose from the banking inquiry. In line with the need for the best possible supervision of funds is the control and management of investor's funds. It is essential that the trustees and managers of the funds be accountable to the fund managers. These amendments will ensure that this is the case, as the funds will comply with the SIS legislation, which requires that the trustees report down to the members and, as I said before, must not be directed by another person. It is one thing to have elected trustees of funds to represent members' interests. However, who those trustees authorise as the fund managers is equally important. Mf Deputy Speaker, the government has made several significant and positive decisions to ensure adequate protection, and this.process will continue as superannuation continues its rise into prominence in the savings pool of the future.· The following are some of the significant main changes proposed by the bill to each of the acts setting up the CSS and the PSS. For instance, clause 4 declares that the object of the amendments proposed by division 2 of part 2 is to ensure the rules of the CSS are consistent with section 58 of the SI(S) Act. Subsection 58(1) of the SI(S) Act broadly provides that the rules must not permit the trustee of a superannuation entity to be subject to direction by any other person. This general· prohibition against directions to trustees is subject to certain exceptions provided in subsection 58(2). In the case of employer sponsored funds, such as the CSS, paragraph 58(2)(e) provides that the employer sponsor-or an associate of an employer sponsor-may direct the trustees in certain circumstances prescribed by the regulations. Regulation 4.03 prescribes the circumstances where an employer sponsor or an associate of an employer sponsor may give a direction to a trustee. Subregulation 4.03(1) provides that such a direction may not be given if the implementation of the direction will result in the fund becoming technically insolvent and if the rights of the members to accrued benefits are adversely affected by the direction. Subregulation 4.03(2) provides five specific circumstances where a qualifying direction may be given. These relate to the admission of new members, the category of members into which a new member or an existing member may be placed, thus the allowing of a person to become an employer sponsor of the fund, the termination of a fund and the appointment of a trustee to an entity that does not have a trust deed. Division2 of the bill amends the CSS Act so that the minister may only direct the Commonwealth board of trustees No.2, the CSS board, in circumstances authorised by section 58 of the SI(S) Act. Subsections 27C(6) and (7) of the CSS Act provide for the minister to issue a statement of Commonwealth government policy in relation to performance of the functions of the CSS board. As the issue of such statements may be considered as providing directions to the board, contrary to the provisions of section 58 of the SI(S) Act, these subsections are being repealed by clause 7 of the bill. As all sections currently providing for the issue of principles by the minister are being repealed from 1 July 1994, clauses 14 and 15 amend sections 153AL and 153AS to provide 1736 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 8 June 1994 for a delegate of the board or the board itself to make determinations before 1 July 1994 on the basis of principles issued by the minister prior to that date. Section 161 of the. CSS Act provides for financial statements issued by the CSS board to be in the form approved by the minister. It also provides that the annual report ·should contain details of a statement or a policy issued to the CSS board by $e minister. Clause 16 of the bill omits these requirements and provides for the form of financial statements to be agreed by the minister and the board. Clause 17 declares that the object of the amendments proposed by division 3 of part 2 is to ensure that the rules of the CSS are consistent with section 59 of the SI(S) Act. Subsection 59(1) of the SI(S) Act broadly provides that the rules of a superannuation entity must not permit any person other than the trustee of a superannuation entity to exercise a discretion under the rules except in certain circumstances. Paragraph 59(1)(a) provides that such a discretion could be·exercised by a non-ttustee if the rules require that trustee to consent to the exercise of the discretion. In addition, paragraph 59(1)(b) pr()vides that, if the entity is an employer-sponsored fund, the discretion which a non-trustee· may exercise must relate to the contributions the employer will be required to pay after the exercise of the discretion; or the discretion must relate to the termination of the fund; or the circumstances of the exercise of the discretion are covered by regulations made for that purpose. Regulation 4.04 prescribes the circumstances when a non-trustee may exercise a discretion. Subregulation 4.04(1) provides that such a discretion may not be exercised if it will result in the fund becoming technically insolvent and if the rights of the memberS to accrue benefits are adversely affected by the exercise of the discretion. . Subregulation 4.04(2) provides five specific circumstances when a discretion may be exercised. These relate to the admission of new members, the category of members into which a new member or an existing member may be placed, the allowing of a person to become an employer-sponsor of the fund, the termination of a fund and the appointment of a trustee or an entity that does not have a trust deed. , Division3 of the bill amends the CSS Act so that the discretionary powers at present exercised by the commissioner or the minister other than those exempted under section 59 of the SI(S) Act are transferred to the CSS board. Section 60 of the SI(S) Act requires that the rules of a superannuation entity must not permit its rules to be amended unless: (a) the trustee has consented to the amendment; or (b) if the entity is an employer-sponsored fund: (i) the amendment relates to the contributions that an employer-sponsor will; after the amendment, be required or permitted to pay to the fund; or (ii) the amendment relates solely to the termination of the fund; or (iii) the circumstances in which the amendment was made are covered by regulations made for that purpose; the amendment is made solely to confer on the trustee the power to consent to amendment of the rules, . (c) the amendment is made solely for the purpose of conferring on the trustee the power to consent to amendments of those rules. . Regulation 4.05 prescribes the circumstances under which the rules of a superannuation entity may be amended. Subregulation 4.05(1) provides that an amendment may not be made, Wednesday, 8 June 1994 MAIN COMMITIEE 1737 if it·will result in the fund becoming technically insolvent, and if the rights of the members to accrued benefits are adversely affected in consequence of the amendment. Subregulation 4.05(2) provides five specific circumstances when an amendment may be made without the consent .of the trustee. These relate to: the admission of new members; the category of members into which a new member or an existing member may be placed; the allowing of a person to become an employer-sponsor of the fund; the termination of a fund; and the appointment of a trustee to an entity that does not have a trustee. Division3 of the bill attempts to amend the CSS Act so that the rules of the CSS may not be amended without the approval of the board. With regard to investment of funds, section 42 of the CSS Act provides that the CSS Board must consult with the Commissioner for Superannuation regarding moneys that are required to be maintained for the purpose of paying benefits under the CSS Act, in the course of managing the fund. As the board will have responsibility for the payment of benefits under the CSS Act, clause 26 of the bill removes the requirement for consultations with the Commissioner of Superannuation. Presently, subsection 42(3) of the CSS Act provides that the board may invest the money of the fund through im investment manager or managers. Subsection 42(4) requires the board, until 30 June 1995, to engage only Commonwealth Funds Management Ltd (CFM) as the investment manager, to invest any money of the fund. Section 33 of the PSS Act places similar restrictions on the board of the PSS. . Under the SICS) Act the trustees are generally responsible for the investment of funds through an investment manager of their choice. This is a discretion vested in the trustees which goes to the essence of prudential management. It may therefore be argued that, as long as the provisions of section 42(4) of the CSS Act and section 33 of the PSS Act require that the trustees of theCSS and the PSS should only engage CFM as investment managers, there is a contravention of section 59 of the SICS) Act,. which provides that the rules of a fund must not alIow any person other than the truste.e to exercise a discretion. There is, however,. scope for the contrary view that parliament made a definite exception to the requirements of section 59 of the SICS) Act, in the case of the CSS, on the discretion to appoint an investment manager, by not repealing the requirements of subsection 42(4) when it amended subsection 42(1), and that therefore the provisions of section 59 of the SICS) Act are subject to the provisions of section 42(4) of the. CSS Act. Againsnhat view, it may be argued that, as section 42(4)iil the CSS Act and section 33 in the PSS Act existed prior to the enactment of the SIS legislation:-which introduced an entirely new legislative framework· for the prudential management of the superannuation industry-any exception to the key provision of section 59 of the SICS) Act should be found in that act or regulations made thereunder. . If the CSS and the PSS, the two funds we are speaking about, are, to be complying funds, it would be best to remove any doubts about whether the legislative measures to appoint CFM as the investment manager until 30 June 1995 create an exception to the provisions of that particular section, section .59 of the SICS) Act, either by amendments to the CSS Act and the PSS Act or by regulations und-r the SICS) Act relating to section 60. As honourable members undoubtedly are aware, this is an extremely wide ranging bill in the work that it does, and I have by no means covered all the aspects of the legislation and its impact. In the short time left, I reinforce the importance ·of .the bill· with respectto supervision of investment by .funds managers. While the· thrust of this bill is to provide 1738 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 8 June 1994 protection for funds; I make some short comments about some possible investment alternatives for the future of superannuation. It is anticipated that growth in superannuation funds will continue and will in fact accelerate. It has been estimated that by' the year 2002 more than $500 billion will be, held in superannuation stocks. This huge ,pool of savings, could provide enormous opportunities for Australian industry investment, and there is a good' argument that a portion of these funds could be used for industry development. If such a proposal were to be considered, the primary concern would have to be the safety of the members' funds. By adequately supervising the investments, and by ensuring that they are spread across different portfolios tominimise the risk, the safety of members' savings should be assured. The, changes to trustees' reporting and supervisory requirements brought about by the amendmenin this bill would already go some way towards this, in respect of Commonwealth superaimuation funds but, of course, further complementary legislation should be considered. It is not likelythatthe superannuation industry will suddenly move in that direction, and I would suggest that perhaps we will need to ensure that superannuation funare legislated in sQme way, to encourage them to invest that pool of funds into industry ;development.,1 am very pleased -o have the opportunity to support the bill before us today. opportunity to congratulate you on the setting up of this. chamber. I also congratulate you on assuming the role oCdeputy spe!lker and on conducting the affairs .of the Parliament of Australia in this chamber. I e}l.tend my congratulatioto the clerkS and the staff of the parliament for their preparation of this chamber and for transforming it from a committroom into the Main Committee chamber. ' . ' The size of the chamber reminds me a little, of the size of the Victorian Legislative Council whence I came. However, it does not have the gracious adornments of that chamber, nor does it have any gold leaf. Nevertheless, I believe that it will be a very good debating chamber. I am sure that the close proximity of the government and the coalition will lead to some very good debateS. I am pleased to be.able to speak on a bill that is before tlieHouse ,on this historic day in the Main Committee chamber. ' I want to address a few comments to the Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill. Superannuation has changed quite dramatically in .this country over recent years. Those changes have led to much confusion and greater complexity than we have ever seen before. There was a time when individual citizens CQuld negotiate their own superannuation with comparative ease. They were abl-to understand theimplicatipns of what the superannuation requirements were, what their benefits would be after paying into it for an extenped period, and what their net benefit would be at the end of that period. Much has changed in the field of superannuation since that time. Change upon change upon change has been'wrought on the superannuation industry over that period. It is now such a complex area that very few people in this nation understand how superannuation works., The superannuation guarantee charge continues to be a, source of concern for many employers. Apart from being an additional impost on the cost of employing every worker, the administrative costs must be added to the already long list of the costs incurred over and above direct worker payments. One of the widespread concerns that I have picked up about the operation of the superannuation guarantee charge is the way in which smalL balances in superannuation funds can be eroded by administrative costs, particularly for itinerant,casual and seasonal workers, who often see their small balances disappear completely. The problem

speaker: Mr Reid (Bendigo) (10.55 A.m.)
theText: -Mr Deputy Speaker, with your indulgence I take theWednesday, 8 June 1994 MAIN COMMITI'EE 1739 is also particularly serious for many women workers because of the broken periods they spend in the work force. I recently had a complaint from a young man in· my' electorate. He was desirous of working and he had a friend who operated a fruit property in Sunraysia, so he went up there to do some fruit-picking. Obviously, he was paid for that work. The superannuation guarantee charge was deducted.from his earnings and was paid into a superannuation fund. I think a sum of a little over $48 was paid into that superannuation fund. After a period of approximately 12 months, this young man discovered to his dismay that the whole of that amount had been swallowed up by administrative charges. This situation is of real concern because that person may take on a number of part-time or itinerant positions and yet all of those small amounts of money would obviously be swallowed up more or less totally by the administrative charges ofthaf fund. So the government has got serious problems with that. I should note that I understand that the Senate has requested that the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation take submissions and, conduct hearings nationwide on the problems associated with that su,perannuation guarantee charge. One of the other issues related to superannuation was the promise made by the government leading up to the 1993 election. That promise was that superannuation funds would be made available for housing. I am sure that the honourable member for Moreton( Mr Gibson) would be well aware of the election promise made that people would bea:ble to use their superannuation funds for housing. Of course, the government has now reneged on that. It has disappointed a lot of young people who have paid into superannuation and who could have had access to, those funds to provide a deposit on a house. The government has reneged on that promise and it is not going to implement the scheme. .Since then the superannuation for housing report was issued by the Senate Select Committee on Superannua:tion. That was in mid-May. The committee took submissions from many interested parties on this issue and the report received unqualified support across Australia. I might add that for the benefit of the honourable member for Moreton. There were many people who were desirous of having those superannuation funds freed up. for housing. The Senate Select Committee on Superannuation did identify a narrow but certainly a significant band of individuals who would be better off being allowed to use their superannuation money to finance the purchase of a home. There are many ways in which that could have assisted people, particularly young people; to get their first home. Of course, now the government has reneged'totally on that promise and those funds will not be available to them. The other .issue that is related to that, concems a letter that I received from Mr Roy Wilkinson, who is a constitu-nt of mine in the Bendigo area and who has spent a lifetime in the life assurance industry. tIis working life has been devoted to that industry. his letter to me he expressed grave. ,?oncerns about the direction in whi-h superannuation and life assurance were heading. He believes that the industry is in danger as a result of a whole range of changes made by the government. They are so far-reaching that people simply do not understand . the complexities . . of it all and the pitfalls that may be involved. 'He does say that the savings potentild of life assurance is one of the major factors that Australia needs in its economic planning and, he has expressed .his concern .at the way the industry is going. He has implored me to put a Cl!.se that common sense be put back into the insurance ,industry and the superannuation industry in Australia. The implementation of the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act imposes an additional cost. The honourable member for Curtin( Mr Rocher), who was in the. chamber earlier, 1740 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 8 June 1994 expressed concerns about the additional costs that would be imposed and the administrative complexity of the superannuation changes that have been made. I can only reiterate them to the honourable member for Moreton, who is the government member present, in the hope that those issues will be taken up. There are also difficulties imposed on public offers of funds too. I think that therelll'e a number of issues that the government needs to address. Superannuation, as I say, has become more and more complex. People do not understand what is happening now with their superannuation, the extent of the changes varying from one year to another. There have been so many changes over the.past three or four years that people are totally confused about the way t4at the superannuation industry does in fact operate. People who do itinerant work. and are moving from job to job are suffering as a result of the administrative· charges of the superannuation funds. I think that that is one issue that the government needs to address very quickly. It needs to do something to simplify the processes of the superannuation industry. The other major issue which I drew attention to was the use of superannuation money for housing, on which the government has let down the public yet again, making promises in the lead-up to the election, building up people's expectations of being able to use their superannuation funds for housing, only to dash those hopes by reneging on its promise. With those few remarks on this historic occasi-n, I will finish my contribution to the debate. after deliberating on the proposals that led to the establishment of this Main Committee. over the past months, we probably take it a little bit for granted, but this first day of operation of this chamber will go down in the annals of history of Australia as quite an historic day. The establishment of the second chamber obviously was. supported by both the government and the opposition and it seems, from its operation so far this morning, that it is going to be on occasions a rather more Civilised place than the main chamber of the House of Representatives. That is the way it has been designed to be. Ironically, the first bill that we are debating here today is a bill that deals with amendments to superannuation for Commoriwealth parliamentarians. It will be interesting to see what the pundits say in 10 or 20 years time when they are writing about the first day's operation of the Main Committee and the first piece of legislation that comes before us. Another irony in the first day's operation of this. Main Committee is that the Main Committee was established primarily to hasten the flow of legislation through the parliament, particularly the lower House, to get the Senate to speed up the process of government in its part of the legislative process. It is designed to give the opposition a better opportunity to speak, to give more members 'an opportunity to speak, and therefore to give a greater number of Australians, through their representatives, an· opportunity to 'be heard on different legislation that is being passed through the parliament, by transferring the passage of non-contentious items of legislation from the House .of Representatives chamber to this second chamber. Yet, on this first day of operation of this chamber, in the House -f Representatives chamber the guillotine will be enforced all day on different items of legislation that are going through. That is the very mechanism that is at the disposal of the government from time to time the use of which we are trying to overcome by establishing this chamber. So let us hope that in the future it does have the effect of eliminating more often the use of the guillotine on legislation which members of the opposition would like to debate in the main chamber but which today a lot of us are not going to get the opportunity to actually debate.
