speaker: Mr Stephen Smith
theText: That is very important. The honourable member for BennelongWednesday, 8 June 1994 MAIN COMMITTEE 1761 submissions, the panel will· decide whether a conference or oral inquiry is necessary. Given that the panel's deliberations do not generally relate to technical legal matters but rather to matters of market behaviour and market standards, it is more appropriate that the parties, rather than their legal advisers, .address the panel at any such oral inquiries. Legal advisers may of course be present to assist but will not be entitled to address the panel. The issue which the honourable member for Tangney has raised is the ability of a person not just to assist but to address the panel. The rule of natural justice, which as a result of the amendment in the name of the Attorney-General will be incorporated, has the effect that a person does have the opportunity to be heard but not necessarily the right to be. heard orally. The rule of natural justice does n()t necessarily require that decision makers hear arguments from a person's legal representatives. It does require that a person have. an adequate opportunity to present his or her case and, whilthe. bill has the effect that a person does not have the right to be represented by a legal adviser, it does enable an adviser to be present and to assist the person in the presentatioq of that case. These amendments have been modelled on the system of pre-decision conferences under the Trade Practices Act. That is a system which, to my understanding, works very well. We ought to have every confidence that similar procedures ·adopted here will work equally well in this area. To return to a point I made earlier, I believe that will prove to be the case because the panel's deliberations .do not relate to technical legal matters· but to matters of market behaviour and market standards. One does not need to have legal representation to make those points adequately. In conclusion, Mr Deputy Speaker, i( I can, in a sense, conclude where I began, I compliment the Attorney-General on his simplification process. The amendments which he has put before the House are all. worthy of support, and the important changes to Corporations Law which are envisaged by this bill reflect, once again, the ongoing commitment that the government has to el)suring that the Corporations Law operates effectively and efficiently, and that the 'interests of all players-and investors, in .particular-are supported by an effective legal regime, which needs to change continually with changing circumstances. The bill. and the amendments which the Attorney has put before the House effectively satisfy those requirements. . in regard to the matter which is beforus, which is the Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill 1994. There have been a number of matters that have concerned the opposition. The panel and the natural justice issues qaturally come to mind. Th.e Attorney-General( Mr Lavarch)has sought to re-establish a process which covers the natural justice issue. It is not the ppposition's proposal to press that matter, but instead to take· up the matter referred to by the previous speaker, the honourable m-mber for Perth( Mr Stephen Smith). That is the area of the panel itself. We just feel that, in the circumstances, despite the .assurances that have been given, natural justice is an issue. I think the terms used were that natural justice need not be served by people giving oral expression to their concern. To me, it is a strange thing indeed that natural justice can be thought to be served by anything other than Someone having the opportunity to, in any way .they think· appropriate; express their objection or concern· about an issue before the government or before a court. So there should be no limitation on the way in which persons

speaker: Mr Cadman (Mitchell) (I2.36 P.m.)
theText: I will not keep. the chamber longiri my comments1762 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 8 June 1994 can express themselves; The limited process of expression being adhered to by the government is not something that is endorsed by the coalition. I will· quickly run through the main provisions of the bill. Firstly, there is the conferral of jurisdiction on lower courts, something that the opposition will not oppose. The next is the clearing hbuse electronic subregister system. I notice that government speakers have said this will have a massive impact, far wider th.an is supposed by many in the industry. The reverse appears to be the case, and there have been expressions of concern from various interests. To quote: . Several listed public companies have adopted artictes which confer on their boards the power to refuse to register a transfer in favour of a company which.is a foreigri company for the purpose of the Foreign Acquisittons and Takeovers Act 1975. See, for example, Equiticorp Industries Ltdv ACllnternationai Ltd. . . The justification of such articles is said to be that if transfers are registered in favour of foreign persons, the company may itself be classified as a foreign company and this may cause it to lose business opportunities in Australia. The Australian Stock Exchange has expressed its view on this matter, and it is not the intention of the opposition to oppose this measure. The third area is the application of corporate law to financial institutions. The bill removes charges over the property of financial institutions for, the registration scheme in the Corporations Law part 3.5, and that will not be opposed. . The Corporations and Securities Panel is an area which is of-concern. The bill seeks to remedy some of the faults by excluding the rules of natural justice in relation to an inquiry. Excluding legal and other advised representative persons before the panel, advisers will be able to be present to assist their client but m.ay not be able to address the panet The bill allows the court to enforce undertakings given to the panel, andbroaderis the jurisdiction of the panel to investigate certain conduct associated with a takeover. . . This is the area of contention. My colleague the honourable member for Tangney( Mr Williams) has moved an amendment seeking to rectify that problem. I have already said that it is my view that persons ought to be able to give expression in these circumstances in any way they see fit, whether it be written, by tape or orally. They ought to have their representative prepared in such a way as to ·beableto do it The argument presented is that· this will work like a pre-hearing tribunal of thTra,de Practices Tribunal under the Trade Practices Act. That is .qne, except I point out to the Attorney that a court .stands behind the panel and the court has the capacity to enforce uridertakings given to the panel. Therefore,no-one could put any blush on the fact that the proceedings before· the panel are not important. They are very important, both to· the individuals and to their organisations. I submit that not to allow legal representation could inhibit the proper and fair pursuit of an issue being considered by the panel. I do not think anybody wants to get itltoa full-blown court situation but there is a court standing behind the panel. That makes it different from a tribunal or a dispute,settling process which is not formal. Before most tribunals or panels there is a process whereby one may not have judges present, such as in social security, veterans' affairs or immigration. There is a large range of processes whereby negotiations and settlement take place before a tribunal or panel. In all these instances there is no court standing behind the panel to enforce the undertakings given to the panel. That is the distinction we want to draw; In this instance there is a court behind the panel and therefore legal representation is valid and should be allowed. So we, are moving our amendment along those lines. Wednesday, 8 June 1994 MAIN. COMMITTEE 1763 I wish to refer' to other factors in·this legislation, such as the notification Of review of decisions and the screen-based trading systems. The Australian Stock Exchange has submitted that the amendments do not provide a sufficient framework for the provision of an efficient market and for ensuring that the interests of the public,and principally those of the smaller investor,.to whom this type of market is directed, are safeguarded. Some of these criticisms are detailed and complex and appear to be influenced by the desire on the part of the ASX to ensure that markets are restricted to the existing forms of markets. That mayor may not be right, but the ASX has offered a comment and a criticism. As the process develops we need to be very sensitive to ensuring that Australia can capitalise on its particular geographic location in South-East Asia and draw on the expertise and security our markets offer in this area. So the government will need to listen to the Australian Stock Exchange. Finally, I mention the conversion 'of companies to no-liability status and the series of other less consequential amendments. I wish to raise two matters in particular-the program of simplification of the Corporations Law and the conduct of the investigation by two members of the Simplification Task Force. Comments were made by Miss Claire Grosse and Dr Robert Eggleson, who hinted that the company register paper would allude to the need to eliminate the requirement of companies to hold registers in multiple locations. They appear to be eminently suited to the task in which they are engaged. That leads me to the second matterthe Attorney-General's comments. reported in the Australian Financial Review on 29 Aprilwhich basically say to the corporate world, 'You get your act together and we will support you.' I think that is a sensible way to go. I am pleased with the tack that is being taken in relation to this matter. The government could move in and be very prescriptive and use black-letter law and heaps of it. However, there is an adopted attitude or an inherited attitude about this. The former Attorney-General was very much of that ilk: he did not want to move to complete preSCription. In the latter days of his term he tried to gain a mix-an interrelationshipbetween black-letter law and fuzzy l-w, and he did that successfully. . I wish. to compliment the present Attorney-General. I hope his actions help to end the difficulti-s .that the country has experienced over. a long period and about which the government really failed to take action until the horses had bolted. It has been too little too late in some ways, but the Attorney-General. is going about it in the right way. Amendment Bill 1994 require a brief examination of the history of the Corporations and Securities Panel. When honourable members look at this history,. they will see that it picks up many of the points made by the previous speakers. The panel was established, as the honourable member for Perth( Mr Stephen Smith) pointed out, as a peer review group to examine conduct and takeover matters referred to it by the ASC. In particular, it was empowered to make declarations of unacceptable conduct and acquisitions' in respect of takeovers, and to. make orders to remedy such conduct. Unfortunately, the first matter that came before the panel 'was the one referred by the honourable member for Tangney( Mr Williams)'-the Titan Hills takeover case. In terms of peer review, it' must be said diat that case was a total disaster because, rather 'than a peer review, it became an exercise in legal technicalities. It was clear' at that point to the government that the panel could not operate without changes to ·facilitate the panel's conduct of inquiries. That is what the government is doing in this legislation. The Attorney-General

speaker: Mr Duffy (Holt) (12.47 P.m.)
theText: The proposed amendments to the Corporations Legislation1764 MAIN COMMITIEE Wednesday, 8 June 1994 ( Mr Lavarch) and the government should be commended for that because I think it is an important panel. It could not work in the past and these amendments will make it work. That is the aspect of the bill that I particularly want to deal with. All of the other matters in the bill are matters of significance, apart from some consequential matters. A large amount of litigation was directly generated by the Titan Hills-Precision Data reverse takeOver. It is true that some of those actions-these points have been made by other peoplesuch as the constitutional challenge to the panel's power, will not come back to haunt us. I think that that has probably ended. However, as I have indicated briefly, it did become clear during the Titan Hills matter that there were a number of other difficulties with the panel's operations. The most obvious difficulty evidenced by that case is that, despite the panel's legislative charter, hearings have to be conducted with little formality and technicality and with as much expedition as possible. There is potential for that process to be totally bogged down as a quasi-legal forum for legal representatives to present lengthy arguments. The factis that there is a precedent, which was touched on by other speakers,although they were not agreeing with it. That precedent is the procedures before the Trade Practices Commission in the early stages. The worrying part about all this is that when the government attempted to go for peer review there was only one case, because the exact opposite happened. It got bogged down in the most extraordinarily complex legal arguments, and something had to be done about that if we were going to make any sense of peer review at all. The member for Tangney raised the issue which Mr Tony Hartnell, former Chairman of the ASC, pointed out in a fairly recent interview. I do not have the quotation in front of me, but Mr Hartnell said words to the effect that we should have a panel with no power to punish but merely a power to publish what it felt about the behaviour and the standards of behaviour that people had engaged in. That is all very well, but what concerns me about that is that there is nothing at all to stop corporate Australia doing precisely that now. There is nothing that the Attorney could do to stop corporate Australia doing precisely that. In fact, the contrary; and that was touched on in the latter part of the speech by the member for Mitchell( Mr Cadman). For a long while, if not for ever, there has been a total lack of a culture ,of peer review in this country. People tend to say that there has been an overreaction to the corporate excesses of the 1980s, and that is why vie had so much legislation in the late 1980s and early 1990s. But it is not an ovel!eaction to something that happened in the 1980s.The history of it, unfortunately, goes back a lot further than that. One thinks of Cambridge Credit, the Korman empire, Reid Murray and Poseidon. Norie of that happened in the 1980s. It goes back well before the 1 9 8 0 s . ' . . There. has been no history of any 'real attempt by those people involved in corporate Australia to deliver peer review. I well recall occasions on which I spoke to a man who can be referred to as one of our leading chief executive officers; the executive director of a leading Australian public company. He always became very concerned when it was put to him that the behaviour that we were seeing in corporate Australia was appalling. He would always respond-and it -as particularly in relation' to the general area of the Corporations Law concerning loans to directorS that he made this respQnse-that in the company of which he was the chief executive and executive director, none of those things happened. I always had to remind him, time and time again, that no-one suggested that they did. As far as anyone could see, in that company there was a record of accountability along the lines that this government has said should be upheld in the area of corporate law in this country. Wednesday, 8 June 1994 MAIN COMMITTEE 1765 This government has said right through its period of government that, where people are dealing with other people's money, a standard of behaviour is required which is far beyond that which might apply if they wanted merely to fritter away their own money. I well recall having to say to that person on many occasions that if, at some stage in the future, he was asked by a judge, 'When did you actually make a strong speech to the Institute of Directors,. the Business Council of Australia or whoever, on what should be the proper behaviour in corporate Australia?' the answer from him at best would have to be, 'Your Honour, I just happened to be passing by at the time.' In many ways that sums up the problem that the government has-and in particular the Attorney-General has-of getting it into the minds of those people that, if they want a culture of peer review, they have to do it. He as Attorney-General cannot do it. This government cannot establish it. The government and the Attorney cannot put a culture into the minds of people; they have to do it themselves. They have not done it. The honourable member for Tangney quoted the eminent Tony Hartnell, for whose drive, initiative and energy as the first Chairman of the Australian Securities Commission I have the greatest respect; and one can understand what Tony Hartnell said, as quoted by the member for Tangney. But the fact is that that is not a criticism of the legislation that the Attorney is bringing before the parliament. Itcannot be a criticism of it, because what they are appealing for-as much as I can understand precisely what the honourable member for Tangney and Mr Hartnell are appealing for-seems to be some body which does not punish but has to publish and, therefore, highlight misbehaviour of corporate Australia in a particular instance. As I said before, there is no question that that is what this government has always been on about. If corporate Australia wants to engage in that sort of self-regulation through peer review, then it should go right ahead. I think there is no question that the last three Attorneys, including the present one, are on record as saying that, if people want to talk about peer review and if they really are serious about it, they should get on with it. The other point made by many people was that this legislation was not necessary. The old, but correct, point was made by them that, if it is not broken, do not fix it. I can tell honourable members that this legislation was necessary because unquestionably it was broken. This panel had to be fixed. It could not operate in the way it did. The government, and in particular the Attorney, should be congratulated for attempting to bring it back on the rails. But again let me emphasise that it still probably will not work unless corporate Australia is prepared to give it a chance to work. If people wish to tum this again into a quasi-court, they will be able to do it through various means. Do not blame the Attorney-General, or the government, if that happens. Corporate Australia should not run around saying, 'The government did not make an effort to bring about peer review'-because it has. That is what this legislation is attempting to do; it is attempting to fix something that was broken, and it was broken in a way which indicated that corporate Australia had not learned a lesson of allowing a body to take its course and, in a limited way, have that peer review. Mr Deputy Speaker, this is only a limited way. The Attorney cannot do it; the government cannot do it. It is up to corporate Australia. I think I have reached the stage where, if I hear one leader of industry in this country again say that he wants more self-regulation or more peer review, I will become ill, because we know that people are not going to do it. If they want to go out and do it, we invite them to start right now. From the moment of this bill, let them show the Attorney and the government that they are capable of conducting peer review, because they have no culture or no record of it to date. 1766 MAIN COMMITTEE ,l Wednesday, 8 June 1994 Mr Deputy Speaker, it being almost 1.00 p.m., I seek leave to continue my remarks at a future time.
